PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
1.  Project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  is  required  in  order  to  produce  a 
mutually agreeable project suitable for ADB financing. The PPTA will (i) develop an investment 
project bankable by ADB loan; (ii) conduct due diligence for technical, economic, financial, 
social, and environmental viability of the project; and (iii) assist the EA in developing required 
documentation for country resource allocation including PC-1 for submission to the Planning 
Commission. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The  PPTA  will  prepare  a  feasibility  study  including  preliminary  designs;  preliminary 
engineering;  cost  estimates;  technical,  financial,  economic,  and  socioeconomic  analysis; 
environmental analysis; social impact assessment; a study for initial benchmark indicators; and 
project administration manual. 
   
3.  Out of 6 potential Border Crossing Points (BCPs) (Torkham and Chaman at Afghanistan 
border, Sost at China, Wagha and Khokhrapar at India border, and Taftan at Iran border), 
Torkham, Chaman, and Wagha were selected as these three BCPs represent key gateways to 
Central Asia and to South Asia both in terms of existing and potential trade and traffic volumes. 
Other donors are undertaking assessments for Torkham, Chaman, and Wagha in order to 
prepare BCP improvement plans. The TA will align its assessment with these ongoing efforts by 
other donors. The TA assessment will be divided into two phases: the 1st phase for developing 
a BCP migration plan and designing the ensuing project; and the 2nd phase for conducting 
technical, economic, financial, social, and environmental due diligence for the selected BCP. 
 
4.  The ultimate goal for BCP modernization is to adopt the single window systems for 
integrated and coordinated border management and further to move to the One-Stop BCP. 
Since the single window systems require supportive legal and institutional frameworks and 
suitable  capacity  of  BCP  operators  which  will  take  considerable  time  to  be  in  place,  the 
migration toward it should be gradual, incremental, and long-term. ADB’s project does not 
intend to jump to a single window system overnight for operation of Torkham, Chaman, and 
Wagha; it would rather upgrade BCP infrastructure gradually and develop the capacity of its 
operators incrementally so that they can best serve the demand of users within the available 
legal and institutional arrangements while making efforts to migrate to a single window system. 
We can call it an interim arrangement between the status quo and the single window system. 
Considering the necessity of this step-wise migration toward the single window system, the TA 
will develop a BCP migration plan and corresponding incremental infrastructure development 
options for Torkham, Chaman, and Wagha. 
 
5.  The BCP migration plan will identify (i) the timeframe from the status quo to the interim 
arrangement and finally to the single window system; (ii) necessary equipment and ICT system 
suitable for each stage; (iii) BCP design and layout suitable for each stage; (iv) BCP security 
arrangement  workable  and  suitable  at  each  stage;  (v)  legal  and  institutional  framework 
supporting BCP management at each stage; (vi) necessary changes in border crossing process 
and procedures suitable for each stage; and (vii) capacity development plan to operate BCPs at 
each stage. The migration plan will be designed to preserve resources invested for the interim 
arrangement in such a way as to be absorbed into the regime of single window systems that will 
follow.

6.  Once the BCP migration plan is developed for Torkham, Chaman, and Wagha, the TA 
will  design  the  ensuing  investment  project.  The  project  components  will  include  (i)  land 
acquisition and relocation of people, if required; (ii) BCP design and layout in line with the 
security requirements (suitable to be further developed to adopt the single window systems 
according to the migration plan) and civil works; (iii) purchase and installation of equipment 
(inspection-related  or  other  administration-related  like  generator,  etc);  (iv)  purchase  (or 
development)  and  installation  of  ICT  hardware  and  software;  (v)  changes  in  cross-border 
process and procedures (minimal, if possible) along with actions required to be taken on behalf 
of the Government; and (vi) capacity development of BCP officials.  
 
7.  During the 2nd phase, technical, economic, financial, social, and environmental viability 
of the designed project will be assessed. Particularly, as part of financial viability assessment, 
the possibility of private sector participation in BCP operation will be looked into.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $950,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB through ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The Government 
will  finance  the  remaining  $150,000  equivalent  in  in-kind  contributions  of  counterpart  staff 
(technical, administrative, and secretarial assigned not only to PMU but also to consultant 
team), office space (suitable for 9 international and 8 national consultants), office equipment 
(work stations and printer), communications (local call and internet connection), and office 
supplies. The Government was advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to 
financing any ensuing project. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services

and being completed in March 2014. Two sets of consultants will be recruited separately:  
(i) 4 international and 4 national consultants as individual; and (ii) 5 international and 5 national 
consultants  as  a  firm.  The  expertise  and  person-months  of  international  and  national

11.  The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The firm will be hired using quality- 
and cost-based selection with a quality to cost ratio of 90:10 on the basis of simplified technical 
proposal. Terms of reference for the consultants are attached in Supplementary Appendix. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  The executing agency (EA) will be the Federal Board of Revenue (FBR). A project 
management unit (PMU) will be established under FBR for overall implementation of the TA 
including supervision of consultants. The PMU will be headed by a project director (Member 
Customs) and be assigned with suitably qualified staff to assist consultants.  
 
13.  An inter-government agency project steering committee will provide overall guidance to 
the PMU for TA implementation. The steering committee will consist of (i) FBR, (ii) Ministry of 
Commerce, (iii) Ministry of Communication, (iv) Ministry of Interior, (v) Ministry of Defense  
(vi) Ministry of Planning and Development, (vii) National Logistics Cell, and (viii) Economic 
Affairs Division. The steering committee will invite representatives of provincial governments, 
FATA  Secretariat,  and  other  relevant  government  agencies  as  necessary.  The  steering 
committee  will  be  chaired  by  Chairman,  FBR  with  the  representatives  of  other  member 
ministries/agencies at the Joint Secretary/equivalent level. The project director will act as a 
secretariat of the committee and regularly report to the steering committee and ADB about the 
progress of the TA. The steering committee will endorse (i) the BCP migration plan for Torkham 
and Wagha; and (ii) the proposed project design for Torkham, Chaman, and Wagha and its 
financing plan. 
 
14.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time).
